She proposes to build a model and test its efficacy on the next expedition at the Arctic Mars Analog in Svalbard (AMASE)—
en_results_raw: batteries. Although the mission team made numerous attempts to revive Opportunity, it was ultimately declared lost in February 2019. The loss of these two rovers highlights the challenges and risks associated with space exploration, particularly when it comes to the harsh Martian environment. Despite these setbacks, NASA has continued to push the boundaries of space exploration, with the Curiosity rover, launched in 2011, still actively exploring the Martian surface. The Perseverance rover, launched in July 2020, has also joined the ranks of Martian explorers, with a focus on searching for signs of past or present life on the Red Planet. The experiences and lessons learned from Spirit and Opportunity have undoubtedly contributed to the design and operation of these newer rovers, enabling them to navigate the unforgiving Martian terrain with greater success. As we look to the future of space exploration, it is essential to acknowledge the pioneering achievements of Spirit and Opportunity, which paved the way for the continued exploration of our celestial neighbor.
